posts._title: Sven Methling – Pigen og pressefotografen AKA The Girl and the Press Photographer (1963)
posts.title: Pigen og pressefotografen
posts.excerpt: A male photographer and a female reporter meet at the newspaper they work for in Copenhagen and become friends. She helps him get an apartment with a marriage of convenience – or so he thinks.
posts.titleEnglish: The Girl and the Press Photographer

posts._title: Buichi Saito – Ai to shi o mitsumete AKA Gazing at Love and Death (1964)
posts.title: Ai to shi o mitsumete
posts.excerpt: Quote:Based on the moving true story of a senior high school student named Michiko (Sayuri Yoshinaga) who contracted a terminal illness and spent the following three years exchanging over 400 letters with her boyfriend Makoto (Mitsuo Hamada).

posts._title: Ulrike Ottinger – Exil Shanghai AKA Exile Shanghai (1997)
posts.title: Exil Shanghai
posts.excerpt: Quote:Fascinating and rich with wry humor, Exile Shanghai is an extraordinary cultural odyssey that affectionately conjures up the lost Jewish world of Shanghai. In the dark days of the 1930s, the Chinese metropolis was the last refuge for Europe’s persecuted Jews—a place that did not demand a visa. Those who managed to find refuge there …

posts._title: Arthur Cantrill & Corinne Cantrill – The Second Journey (To Uluru) (1981)
posts.title: The Second Journey (To Uluru)
posts.excerpt: Filmed years after “At Uluru” (1978) in very different conditions, the film showcases the burnt landscape around a monolith in a land inhabited for millennia.“As the camera moves gently from afar into the very heart of the monolith, the magic of the holiest site of the Aborigines unfolds in shimmering nuances of light.Shot at different …

posts._title: Yugantar – Tambaku Chaakila Oob Ali AKA Tobacco Embers (1982)
posts.title: Tambaku Chaakila Oob Ali
posts.excerpt: Quote:Tambaku Chaakila Oob Ali documents, re-enacts, and takes forward one of the largest movements of unorganized labor of its time and context, which sparked unionizing processes across India throughout the 1980s. In the spirit of mobilizing for the leftist labor and the women’s movements the Yugantar collective spent four months with female tobacco factory workers …

posts._title: Andrzej Kondratiuk – Pelnia AKA Full Moon (1979)
posts.title: Pelnia
posts.excerpt: Quote:Although neither his wife nor his friends can understand him, a Varsovian architect leaves the hustle bustle of Warsaw to find peace and make new friends while living in a small village. Quote:Andrzej Kondratiuk made “Pełnia” ten years after his famous feature debut “A hole in the ground”. This intimate tale of escape from the …

posts.title: Picasso Trigger
posts.excerpt: Synopsis:Donna (Dona Sper) and her partner Tanya (Hope Marie Carlton) are two beautiful female secret agents sent to stop the international villain Picasso Trigger (John Aprea) in this action spy thriller. Travis Abilene (Steve Bond) is the agent assigned to gather a group of sometimes questionable abilities to combat the international foes. Picasso Trigger is …

posts._title: Jimmy Wang Yu – Long hu dou AKA The Chinese Boxer AKA Hammer of God (1970)
posts.title: Long hu dou
posts.excerpt: Synopsis:Wang Yu takes the title role as a young kung fu student who prides himself on his skill and his upright standing. These skills are tested and defeated when a local rival enlists the help of a group of Japanese fighters who then kill most of Wang Yu’s school. The injured hero barely escapes with …
posts.titleEnglish: The Chinese Boxer AKA Hammer of God

posts.title: Parêdo
posts.excerpt: Quote:Four youths share a two bedroom apartment in a corner of Tokyo. A series of assault cases occur in the same district. Eighteen year old Satoru, a male prostitute, joins them as a new house mate. Their daily life slowly starts to change.

posts._title: Zoltán Fábri – Hannibál tanár úr AKA Professor Hannibal (1956)
posts.title: Hannibál tanár úr
posts.excerpt: Zoltan Fabri’s 1956 Hungarian feature about the persecution of an educator (played for both laughs and great pathos by Ernö Szabó) whose essay about Hannibal and the Punic Wars in a school bulletin is deemed unflattering to the Mussolini regime. A beautifully shot, modest masterpiece which is, as the cliche goes, as timely today as …
